answers.title: use setState method correctly

answers.body_markdown:
1. _Don't_ reference `this.state`. Use callback variant of `setState`, get current state from there. That'll explicitly guard you against the "changed the state, but the state hasn't changed yet" situations.

And 2. Simply put those two updates into one run of `setState`:
```
this.setState((prevState) => ({
    counter: prevState.counter + 1,
    hasButtonBeenClicked: prevState.counter + 1 > 0 }));
```

> is it possible to switch to a previous stack frame and continue

Yes, you can do it with [reverse debugging][1].

When you get segfault, run `reverse-finish` to go out of the current frame in reverse direction. You will stop in the previous frame where you are about to call the function that caused a segfault.

ii) Copy db-name.out file using sftp/ssh to remote MySQL server:

answers.body_markdown:
> Azure Devops - Mvn update-version is not working as part of CI build

According to the document [MojoExecutionException][1], this exception is not generated by the Maven core itself but by a plugin. 

For your case, it seems you are using the `maven-release-plugin:2.5.2`. The cause of the problem seems to be that that plugin checks out the branch in detached head state. HEAD is a pointer which tells you which branch you are on. Pipelines checks out a specific revision/commit when it runs to help test each change to a project, leaving the working copy in "detached head" mode. Maven wants to make additional commits to your repo to record the changes to your `pom.xml`, and so must be on a branch.

So, to resolve this issue, you can try to reset the branch you want to release from, to the current commit. Assuming you're working from master, you would add command line task at the beginning of your pipeline:

    git checkout master

Then, you'll be on head: master, and able to run maven release.

You can check [this thread][2] and [this thread][3] for some more details.

Hope this helps.


  [1]: https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/MAVEN/MojoExecutionException
  [2]: https://www.roytuts.com/jenkins-detecting-the-current-branch-failed-fatal-ref-head-is-not-a-symbolic-ref/
  [3]: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/20351051/git-fatal-ref-head-is-not-a-symbolic-ref-while-using-maven-release-plugin
answers.title: Azure Devops - Mvn update-version is not working as part of CI build

Both the insert statements seem to have missing partition part in them.

For a partitioned table `tab1` with a partition column and two other columns, the data should be inserted like the below, 

```INSERT INTO tab1 partition ("abcdef") values (1, 2)```

So, the provided INSERT statement should throw an error like this

```
Error while compiling statement: FAILED: SemanticException 1:12 Need to specify partition columns because the destination table is partitioned. Error encountered near token 'my_table'
```

Also, answering to your original question - In Hadoop you cannot create files or directories those have the characters `/` or `:` as a part of its name. 

So the better way of creating partition is to exclude these characters from the name.

answers.body_markdown:
You already loaded the `SDK` dll, there is no need for an additional attribute. 

The names exported from `SDK.dll` are attributes of the object returned from `ctypes.cdll.LoadLibrary()` (an instance of the [`CDLL` class](https://docs.python.org/3/library/ctypes.html#ctypes.CDLL)), which you assigned to the name `dll`.

So if `SDK.dll` exports a function named `Service`, you can call it with:

    dll.Service()

See the [*Accessing functions from loaded dlls* section](https://docs.python.org/library/ctypes.html#accessing-functions-from-loaded-dlls) of the `ctypes` documentation.

Take into account that `ctypes.cdll` expects DLLs to use *C function export declarations*. C++ namespaces are not exported. 

You may also be dealing with a DLL that uses the Windows-only `stdcall` conventions, at which point you need to use the `ctypes.windll` (assumes functions return `int` by default) or the `ctypes.oledll` (assumes `HRESULT` return values) library loaders. There is no easy way to detect *from the DLL alone* what calling convention it expects. If you have the corresponding `.h` header files (I would expect an SDK to have those), then see if the functions that are defined use `__cdecl` or `__stdcall`. Otherwise, just try to use the DLL with `cdll`, and if you get a `ValueError: Procedure called with not enough arguments (<n> bytes missing) or wrong calling convention` exceptions switch to using `cdll.windll` instead.
answers.title: how to find dll functions from python?

answers.body_markdown:
@Dibba Butt If you don't really want to change the datatype from string to datetime on the database level.
As a workaround you can first fetch the data and store it into a list (Might have to fetch all the data). 

Then filter the yourList to obtain the result between the ranges by using DateTime.ParseExact. Refer to the sample code below.


    var res = yourList.ToList().Where(a => DateTime.ParseExact(a.st,"dd-MM-yyyy",CultureInfo.InvariantCulture) <= startDate && DateTime.ParseExact(a.st,"dd-MM-yyyy",CultureInfo.InvariantCulture) => endDate).ToList(); 


**Note: Modifying your code to obtain solution. Use below code instead.** 

        // The first List without datetime range filter.
        
            var entity =
                            (from o in iDb.IN_STG_EOM_ORDERS.Select(s => new
                            {
                                s.id,
                                s.PickTicketNumber,
                                s.OrderNumber,
                                s.OrderID,
                                s.OrderDate,
                                s.FirstName,
                                s.LastName,
                                s.OrderShippingAddress1,
                                s.OrderAmount,
                                s.OrderAmountShipping,
                                s.OrderAmountTotal,
                                s.OrderShippingStatus,
                                s.OrderGiftWrapping,
                                s.IsError,
                                s.OrderShippingStatusId,
                                s.OrderStatusId,
                                s.LastModifiedDate,
                                s.OrderDate,
                            }).Where(w => w.OrderShippingStatusId != 0 && w.OrderStatusId != "29" && w.OrderShippingStatusId < 200 && w.OrderShippingStatusId != null).ToList();
    
    // Now applying the filter.
    
    var res = entity.Where(a => DateTime.ParseExact(a.OrderDate,"dd-MM-yyyy",CultureInfo.InvariantCulture) <= startDate && DateTime.ParseExact(a.OrderDate,"dd-MM-yyyy",CultureInfo.InvariantCulture) => endDate).ToList(); 

**Note:** Use res which will be filtered based on the date range you provide. Your start and end date should be in dd-MM-yyyy format.

answers.body_markdown:
As far as I know and have read about EF Core, database first approach is only supported to generate a `context` once. After creating a `context` from an existing database you have to use migrations for database modifications. `Scaffold-DbContext` will re-created the whole `context` on every execution. ([Here is the source.](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/ef/core/managing-schemas/scaffolding#updating-the-model))  
Of Course you could re-create after every database modificytion a new `context` - like mentioned in the linked article, but I would suggest to use the code first approach. You could better track all your database changes and it supports you and your colleaugs to work on one project at the same time.  

Here is a [link with further information about `-Table` switch](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/ef/core/managing-schemas/scaffolding). It is used to define which tables are included in `context` at generation process.

> All tables in the database schema are reverse engineered into entity types by 
> default. You can limit which tables are reverse engineered by
> specifying schemas and tables.
> 
> The `-Schemas` parameter in PMC and the `--schema` option in the CLI can
> be used to include every table within a schema.
> 
> `-Tables` (PMC) and `--table` (CLI) can be used to include specific tables.

answers.body_markdown:
Based on the [Incrementally copy data][1] in ADF, mongo db connector is not supported so far.
My workaround is adding a outside static variable to store every end time of pipeline.

***Step1-*** Add an azure function activity after the copy activity. If the copy activity executes successfully, pass the end of execution time into azure function as parameters. Such as `utcnow()`:https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/data-factory/control-flow-expression-language-functions#date-functions

***Step2-*** Inside azure function method, store the `time` into some place which could be accessed later,such as Blob Storage.

***Step3-*** Next trigger run,get the last execute time with [Look Up activity][2] from blob storage before the copy activity and set it into [set variable activity][3] so that you could use it in the next step.

***Step4-*** Add [filter condition][4] in the mongo db source dataset with the value of set variab le activity. 

Hope it helps you.


  [1]: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/data-factory/tutorial-incremental-copy-overview
  [2]: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/data-factory/control-flow-lookup-activity
  [3]: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/data-factory/control-flow-set-variable-activity
  [4]: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/data-factory/connector-mongodb#copy-activity-properties

answers.title: Typescript Array[T] accepts {..T} as valid type

answers.body_markdown:
This appears to be indeed a problem with Typescript itself:

    let c: number[] = { ...[0, 1, 2] }; // compiles
    c.fill(0) // runtime error
    
    let d: number[] = Object.assign({}, [0, 1, 2]);  // compiles
    d.fill(0) // runtime error

Moreover, this also compiles and breaks at run-time:

    class E {
        method() { }
    }
    
    let e: E = Object.assign({}, new E)
    e.method() // runtime error

[PG](http://www.typescriptlang.org/play/index.html#code/DYUwLgBAhgXBB2BXAtgIxAJwNoF0IF4IBvCUeAczAAs4BmAGggCIAGJuFxpgRnYm64AmPoIgBfANwQIAehkQA9gGtGAEwUgAzvADkkAMYLkABwCWoAFAXQkVHCRpMuAhADyqAFYh9YAHRRNTVNyeAAKIjFGEjJKGggGZjYOLl44AWZhOFExAEopOUUVCHUtXQMjM0trcAh9exR0bDxCEl82rE5+RkE8SVl5QxNzLQt9XwAzc2BQlhz+iAxEeDBTZBAITAwFDCsbYvrHJpd3Lx9-QOCwiMYOxnSevOkCwcqR1QmpmbmCxeXV9c22ys+mAAU0EAAosQLNJpGtqApVKE5iQxBY0dVICA4FDCCdvH4wZdwpEECAAO6QnIWEC+eFURHI+a-FZrDYYLY7CxAA)

I guess this is because `Object.assign` is declared as

    assign<T, U>(target: T, source: U): T & U;

which is incorrect, since what `assign` returns doesn't actually extend `U`. The return type of `assign` should be something like `T & OwnProperties<U>`, but this is currently not possible, see

- https://github.com/microsoft/TypeScript/issues/28801
- https://github.com/microsoft/TypeScript/issues/9726
answers.title: Typescript Array[T] accepts {..T} as valid type

So anyone else facing this issue I solved it by using `iconv` https://www.npmjs.com/package/iconv stream option like this:

        const iconv = new Iconv('CP1255', 'utf-8');

        return new Promise((resolve, reject) => {
            const s = fs.createReadStream(file.tempFilePath)
                .pipe(es.pipe(iconv))
                .pipe(es.split())

All I had to do was pipe iconv to the stream

> Chunked data Say you are reading data in chunks from a HTTP stream.
> The logical input is a single document (the full POST request data)
> but the physical input will be spread over several buffers (the
> request chunks).
> 
> You must accumulate the small buffers into a single large buffer
> before performing the conversion. If you don't, you will get
> unexpected results with multi-byte and stateful character sets like
> UTF-8 and ISO-2022-JP.
> 
> The above only applies when you are calling Iconv#convert() yourself.
> If you use the streaming interface, node-iconv takes care of stitching
> partial character sequences together again.
answers.title: Nodejs reading large txt files and converting encoding

When you call Mongoid.override_client(:attachDb), all query and command to database will connect to the client you have overridden in this thread.
Like:

Default scope of an entity is Singleton - Here only one instance of your bean will be created and that will be returned in every subsequent request call.


In case of Prototype scope, new bean instance will be created for each request to that bean.
